phrase.item: Agriculture has existed in Wakhan since ancient times.
We distinguish four agricultural seasons.
Winter is cold: we only scatter the bedding for the livestock and prepare the fertilizer.
The more fertilizer, the better the harvest will be.
We only scatter the fertilizer under the large livestock; the manure from the small livestock is without dirt, without ash, and without garbage (waste).
The best fertilizer for the earth is the one from the small livestock.
When there is a lot of manure in the stable (when it has accumulated) in winter, we remove it and stack (pile) it up.
We mix grass, leguminous flour, barley stems, and alfalfa with it and we give it to the cattle so that they can fertilize for the plows.
In the winter we prepare the material: plows, yokes, thongs of the yokes, plowshares, shafts; we prepare the material by pair depenending on number of cattle couples.
These are only winter jobs (chores).
When the chogoun(?) arrives, the sowing begins little by little.
We hitch [on] the plows, for seven to ten days, just until noon so that the cattle get used to working.
We labor from morning to night:
At noon we bring grass to the field and the people feed their cattle, i.e. it's their lunch.
We must not make the cattle (push the cattle to) move very fast.
Some cows can weaken: we coat their hoovess and horns in fat (grease).
When the plowing is done. we let the cows roam freely in the mountains and the brushwood.
Once a week their master (owner) goes to see his livestock.
The earth requires two kinds of work: we make embankments and furrows.
For the furrows, we begin begin by moistening the earth.
Next we plow it, then we harrow it. Then we bring in fertilizer.

When we scatter and spread the fertilizer, we trace lines because, when we throw the seeds by hand without lines, the field is not uniformly seeded; this way the seeder looks at each line and throws the seeds.
After the sowing, we plow.
When the plowing is done, we harrow once more to prepare for the tracing of the irrigation furrows.
The farrows are traced by the cows (oxen?).
If the field is large, we divide the furrows in the middle; we trace an intermediary transversal furrow, the longitudinal furrows are thus shortened.
And this is how we proceed on the rich and low fertile plots: we do not trace long furrows, we make furrows and intermediary and transversal barrages with a shovel.
Next we make the embankments (canals).
We trace the transversal furrow through the middle of the plot.
It divides the field in two, three or four parts.
There are two types of longitudinal transversal furrows: single and double.
They separate the embakment from the neighboring furrow.
The embankments are separated from one another by flat beds [of earth].
At harvest time, we "rank/classify" (Note: very unure about verb in this sentence, most likely incorrect) each intermediary furrow, each embankment, each transversal embankment.
Is sequence ADJ DET NOUN licit in ADJ NOUN Iranian languages not in heavy contact with Turkic (Caspian languages)?
On the earth where the furrows are traced, the farmers dig channels for water, make embankments, clean the intermediary furrows [and] proceed with the first watering.
That last -əm must be a transcription error in GSK
There are two waterings that are done in the same way: we open [up] the water in each furrow separately.
Then we let it flow everywhere, i.e. we reunite (connect) all of the furrows and if there is a lot of water, everything can become flooded.

But there are some fields that we musn't water in the full heat of the daytime because the field is dried out by the wind, [thus] it doesn't absorb the humidity (moisture), the shoots wither, [and] shrivel.
especially the [fava] beans, the barley and the wheat.
We only water them once the sun has set, either at night, or at dawn, because at these times the water is cold.
Cold water isn't harmful.
But we only proceed with the first watering of the day. (note: unsure about this sentence - very unclear)
We let a bit of water flow because in the (scorching) heat the earth (ground) drinks a lot.
ojista = ?
First we sow the barley, then the [fava] beans, then the wheat, and finally the millet.
We water the barley nine times, the [fava] beans twelve times, the wheat fifteen times; we can also water [them] even more.
When the sprouts become green, they cover the irrigation furrows; so we weed (hoe) the field; if the earth is sandy, we weed it up to three times as there are many weeds.
During the harvest, the weeds harm the farmers' hands and they grow very quickly.
The barley is the first to mature.
We harvest the barley, we tie it in bunches; we harvest the [fava] beans and the grass peas and we put them in sheaves.
We also tie the wheat and the millet in bunches, and so that the barley and wheat dry we make bales.
We fan out the sheaves of [fava} beans and we place the millet standing up.
Next we gather them, we put the wheat in stacks (note: in a grinder - instead of stacks - unsure) on the the threshing floor, [and] we place the millet standing up.
We pack the barley in (large) baskets, we bring it to the threshing floor, we spread it out
and we begin the threshing.
When there is a large threaching, we harness up ten to twelve heads of cattle side to side and we make them turn.
We take a special a special container [by hand] for the manure, so that the livestock doesn't soil the threshed grain.
When the mass of grain is softened, we put it in piles and when the wind kicks up, we winnow it.
When the grain begins to detatch itself, we gather it with a shovel and the women sweep the area.

When the grain is entirely detatched we clean it with a sieve and we put it in piles; we trace lines around the piles, and on the piles we draw eyes, we place a cap (fabric hat-like thing) on the top. When someone sits near a pile, they turn the face (unsure whether the person's face or the face on the grain pile) towards Mecca, and first take a measurement (of wood?) from this pile of grain, [and] they put it in a sac.
biz?

We beat the grain like the barley, but if there is a lot we put it in a mill in the area. After having placed it standing up oin the field, we bring the millet to the area and we place it standing up once again.
Once the threshing is finished and we have brought the grain to the house, we gather the straw to feed the livestock in the winter.
We call the bail mixed with dirt "pitkben", we save it as litter, in the winter we scatter it for litter.
When the harvest is finished, we organize a celebration called "dosowiz."
When we sweep the area, this is called "kampirek."
If it's millet, donkeys help to beat it.
We make a bed of hay from the leftover millet stems.
In the summer, we also sow the alfalfa and we water it.
When the alfalfa reaches maturity we leave a parcel for the seeds.
We gather the grain, i.e. the alfalfa seeds.
Next the grains will be sown.
In autumn there is a lot of work: threshing, reaping (mowing), harvesting, gathering of ears, work on the threshing area.
Some people bring their livestock to the pastures once the plantings become green so that they are protected from (potential) damages.
After the harvestong of the barley and the ears, we wet (water) and we plow.
This way we can plow all of the land so that the spring's work is lightened: sow without plowing.
If we don't plow the fields [in autumn] they will yield a small harvest, we call these fields "chakhtchakori."
